revision.comment: /* Video games */"2018" got replaced by "2019" in the Video games section of Snapshot Games' main page.
revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Snapshot Games | logo =File:Snapshot Games Logo.jpg | type =[[Privately Held Company|Private]] | industry = [[Video game developer]] | genre = | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | founder = | defunct = | area_served = | products = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = 30 | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | footnotes = | intl = | founders = [[Julian Gollop]]
David Kaye | foundation =2013 | location_city = [[Sofia]] | location_country = [[Bulgaria]] | location = | locations = | homepage = {{URL|http://snapshotgames.com/}} }} '''Snapshot Games''' is an [[independent video game developer]] headquartered in [[Sofia]], [[Bulgaria]].{{Cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/2017/04/25/inspired-by-x-com-snapshot-games-creates-phoenix-point-for-the-fall-2018/|title=Inspired by X-COM, Snapshot Games is creating Phoenix Point for fall 2018|date=2017-04-25|website=VentureBeat|access-date=2017-06-16}} Snapshot Games was founded in 2013 by [[Julian Gollop]] and David Kaye. Gollop is recognized for creating the ''[[X-COM]]'' video game franchise in the 1990s with ''[[UFO: Enemy Unknown]]'' and ''[[X-COM: Apocalypse]]''.{{Cite web|url=https://www.polygon.com/2017/5/2/15516198/phoenix-point-fully-funded-stretch-goals-xcom-spiritual-successor-julian-gollop|title=X-COM spiritual successor Phoenix Point hits $500K crowdfunding goal|last=Hall|first=Charlie|date=2017-05-02|website=Polygon|access-date=2017-06-16}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.gamereactor.eu/news/532373/Phoenix+Point+has+hit+its+funding+target/|title=Gamereactor UK|website=www.gamereactor.eu|access-date=2017-06-16}}{{Cite web|url=https://geekreply.com/geek-culture/2017/04/29/phoenix-point-spiritual-successor-x-com-can-backed-fig|title=Phoenix Point, the Spiritual Successor to X-Com, Can Be Backed on Fig|website=geekreply.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-06-16}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.usgamer.net/articles/x-com-creator-returns-to-the-genre-with-phoenix-point|title=X-COM Designer Returns To the Genre With Phoenix Point|last=Williams|first=Mike|website=USgamer|language=en-US|access-date=2017-06-16}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2017/06/05/phoenix-point-boss-battle-gameplay-revealed|title=Phoenix Point Boss Battle Gameplay Revealed|last=Osborn|first=Alex|date=2017-06-05|website=IGN|language=en-US|access-date=2017-06-16}} Gollop also is the [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] of Snapshot Games. In addition to Gollop, the company includes about eight developers who are industry veterans with years of previous experience working for [[Ubisoft|Ubisoft Sofia]], [[Crytek Black Sea]], and other Bulgaria studios. ==History== On November 12, 2013, Snapshot Games was founded as a [[Privately held company|privately held corporation]] in the state of [[California]] of the [[United States]].{{Cite web|url=https://businesssearch.sos.ca.gov/CBS/SearchResults?SearchType=CORP&SearchCriteria=snapshot+games&SearchSubType=Keyword|title=Business Search - Business Entities - Business Programs {{!}} California Secretary of State|website=businesssearch.sos.ca.gov|language=en|access-date=2017-06-16}} However, it is based in [[Bulgaria]] where its [[Chief executive officer|CEO]], [[Julian Gollop]], lives and where video game development costs are about one-third of what they would be for a similar [[Independent video game developer|studio]] in the [[United States]]. In April 2014, Snapshot Games launched a [[Kickstarter]] to [[crowdfund]] the development of its first [[video game]], ''[[Chaos Reborn]]''.{{Cite web|url=https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1206403106/chaos-reborn-from-the-creator-of-the-original-x-co/|title=Chaos Reborn - From the Creator of the Original X-COM|website=Kickstarter|language=en-US|access-date=2017-06-16}} The effort was successful, generating over $210,000. The game was made available through the [[Early Access]] program of [[Steam (software)|Steam]] on December 9, 2014 before it was released officially on October 26, 2015.{{Cite web|url=https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2015/10/09/chaos-reborn-release-date-2/|title=X-COM Creator’s Chaos Reborn Is Born This Month|last=Meer|first=Alec|date=2015-10-09|website=Rock, Paper, Shotgun|language=en-US|access-date=2017-06-16}} The game received a score of 86/100 on review aggregation website [[Metacritic]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/chaos-reborn|title=Chaos Reborn|website=Metacritic|access-date=2017-06-16}} ''[[PC Gamer]]'' awarded it a score of 87%, saying "A true wizard’s wheeze, and a fine return for one of gaming’s oldest tactical classics."{{Cite news|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/chaos-reborn-review/|title=Chaos Reborn review|work=[[PC Gamer]]|access-date=2017-06-16|language=en}} The game also was nominated for a [[Golden Joystick Award]] in the 2015 Best Indie Game category but lost to ''[[Kerbal Space Program]]''.{{Cite news|url=http://geeksyndicate.co.uk/news/the-golden-joystick-awards-2015-voting-now-open/|title=The Golden Joystick Awards 2015 - Voting Now Open - Geek Syndicate|date=2015-09-04|work=Geek Syndicate|access-date=2017-06-16|language=en-GB}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/newsbeat/article/34679591/golden-joysticks-2015-the-witcher-3-wild-hunt-wins-five-gaming-awards|title=Golden Joysticks 2015: The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt wins five gaming awards - BBC Newsbeat|date=2015-10-30|website=BBC Newsbeat|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-06-16}} [[Julian Gollop]] teased the development of a new [[video game]], ''[[Phoenix Point]]'', on [[Twitter]] on March 18, 2016.{{cite web|url=https://www.vg247.com/2016/03/18/x-com-creator-julian-gollop-teases-new-game-phoenix-point/ |title=X-COM creator Julian Gollop teases new game Phoenix Point |publisher=[[VG 247]]|date=2016-03-18 |accessdate=2017-06-13}}{{cite web|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/julian-gollop-announces-new-game-phoenix-point/ |title=Julian Gollop announces new game, Phoenix Point |publisher=[[PC Gamer]] |date=2016-03-18 |accessdate=2017-06-13}} For the next year, Snapshot Games worked on designing and producing the game.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/2017-04-26-there-is-no-plan-b |title=There is no Plan B |publisher=Gameindustry.biz |date=2017-04-26 |accessdate=2017-06-13}} After investing $450,000 into this first year of development, the company launched a [[Fig (company)|Fig]] crowdfunding campaign in April 2017 to obtain the $500,000 they budgeted to complete the game.{{cite web|url=https://www.polygon.com/2017/4/25/15407662/phoenix-point-julian-gollop-fig |title=Phoenix Point's Fig campaign promises new take on classic X-COM formula |publisher=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]|date=2017-04-25 |accessdate=2017-06-13}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.fig.co/campaigns/phoenix-point|title=Phoenix Point Crowdfunding Campaign|website=Fig|language=en|access-date=2017-06-16}} The future of Snapshot relied on the success of the campaign. "There is no Plan B," Gollop said to the press at the time. The campaign was successful, raising more than $765,000 from over 10,300 different contributors. Snapshot Games has committed to release ''[[Phoenix Point]]'' in 2019.{{cite web|url=https://www.polygon.com/2017/5/2/15516198/phoenix-point-fully-funded-stretch-goals-xcom-spiritual-successor-julian-gollop |title=X-COM spiritual successor Phoenix Point hits $500K crowdfunding goal |publisher=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] |date=2017-05-02 |accessdate=2017-06-13}}{{cite web|url=http://wccftech.com/phoenix-point-x-com-creator-funding-fig/ |title=Phoenix Point by X-COM Creator Seeks Funding on Fig |publisher=wcctech.com |date=2017-04-26 |accessdate=2017-06-13}} ==Video games== {| class="wikitable" ! Year ! Title ! Genre(s) ! Themes ! Mode(s) ! Platforms |- | 2015 | ''[[Chaos Reborn]]'' | [[Tactical role-playing game]] | [[Dystopia]]n [[Fantasy]] | [[Multiplayer video game|Multiplayer]], [[Single-player video game|Single-player]] | rowspan="2" | [[Microsoft Windows]]
[[OS X]]
[[Linux]] |- | 2019 | ''[[Phoenix Point]]'' | [[Turn-based tactics]], [[Strategy video game|Strategy]] | [[Science fiction|Science Fiction]] [[Horror fiction|Horror]] | [[Single-player video game|Single-player]] |} == References == {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{Official website|snapshotgames.com}} [[Category:Companies based in Sofia]] [[Category:Entertainment companies established in 2013]] [[Category:Independent video game developers]] [[Category:Video game companies of Bulgaria]] [[Category:Video game development companies]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox amusement park | name = Swiss Vapeur Parc | image = <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Svparc.gif]] --> | caption = The Logo of Swiss Vapeur Parc | location = [[Le Bouveret]], [[Valais]], [[Switzerland]] | season = April through November | opening_date = June 6, 1989 | previous_names = | area = 17'000 m² (4.2 acres) | rides = 1 (as it is a train circuit) * 6 Trains running on Benzine * 9 Steam Trains | owner = | general_manager = | homepage = [http://swissvapeur.ch/en Swiss Vapeur Parc] |coordinates={{Coord|46|23|00|N|6|51|30|E|display=it|region:CH-VS_type:city(800)_source:dewiki}} }}
The '''Swiss Vapeur Parc''' is a [[miniature park]] in [[Le Bouveret]], a village on [[Lac Léman]], [[Switzerland]]. It was opened on June 6, 1989, by an International Festival of Steam (therefore steam trains). When the park opened its total surface area was 9000 m² (2.2 acres), but the park expanded and as of 2007, the park covers a surface area of 17'000 m² (or 4.2 acres). In 1989, the park possessed only 2 locomotives (one running on benzine and one on steam). As of 2007, the number of trains running on benzine has sextupled while the number of steam trains has increased to 9 trains. By March 31, 2007, the Park has had 2'126'000 visitors.
Every June the park is host to the International Steam Festival.
==Image gallery==
<gallery> Image:Crossing bridge steam.jpg|A train crosses a bridge in the parc Image:Leaving chablais city.jpg|Two trains leaving the fictional "Chablais City" Image:Reparations.jpg|A train being oiled Image:Tank engine 1.jpg|A tank engine Image:Train shed.jpg|The first train shed </gallery>
==External links== *[http://www.swissvapeur.ch/en/ The Official Website] *[http://swissvapeur.ch/pages/presse/_communique_2007-en.pdf Press Communique 2007] {{commons category}}

[[E. Duke Vincent]] | editor = Michael B. Hoggan | cinematography = | camera = [[Single-camera setup|Single-camera]] | runtime = 45–48 minutes | company = [[Spelling Television]] | distributor = | channel = [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] | picture_format = | audio_format = | first_aired = {{Start date|1992|08|27}} | last_aired = {{End date|1992|11|26}} }} '''''The Heights''''' is an American musical drama series that aired Thursday at 9:00 pm on the [[Fox network]] from August to November 1992. ==Synopsis== ''The Heights'' centers on a fictional band (also called The Heights) made up of mostly working-class young adults. Episodes regularly featured one of their songs. The eventual theme song for the show, "[[How Do You Talk to an Angel]]" (sung by cast member [[Jamie Walters]]), went to number one on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] chart, and was the first song from a television show to top the Hot 100 since 1985, as well as the first song by a fictional band to top the Hot 100 since 1969. ''The Heights'' premiered on August 27, 1992, to low ratings, and never gained a substantial audience. Fox canceled the series less than a week after the theme song fell from the number one spot.{{cite book|last=Bronson|first=Fred |title=The Billboard Book Of Number 1 Hits|publisher=Billboard Books|year=2003|edition=5|pages=812|isbn=0-8230-7677-6}} ==Cast== *[[Jamie Walters]] as Alex O'Brien *[[Camille Saviola]] as Shelley Abramowitz *[[Alex Désert]] as Stan Lee *[[Charlotte Ross]] as Hope Linden *[[Zachary Throne]] as Lenny Wieckowski *[[Donnelly Rhodes]] as Harry Abramowitz *Jon Cuthbert as Sean McDougall *Shawn David Thompson as J.T. revision.comment: /* Foreworld SideQuests */
revision.text:
{{original research|date=March 2016}} {{Infobox book | name = The Mongoliad | title_orig = | translator = | image = Mongoliad splash screen.jpg | caption = Application [[splash screen]] for ''The Mongoliad'' | author = {{plainlist| *[[Neal Stephenson]] *[[Greg Bear]]}} | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | subject = [[Middle Ages]], [[Mongol Empire]] | genre = | publisher = Subutai Corporation | pub_date = 2010 | english_pub_date = | media_type = [[Smartphone]], [[World Wide Web|Web]], Print | pages = | isbn = 978-1-61218-236-0 | isbn_note = (paperback) | oclc = 764354919 | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }}
'''''The Mongoliad''''' is a fictional narrative set in the ''Foreworld Saga'', a [[secret history]] transmedia franchise developed by the Subutai Corporation.<ref name=cnet/> ''The Mongoliad'' was originally released in a serialized format online, and via a series of [[iOS]] and [[Android (operating system)|Android]] apps, but was restructured and re-edited for a definitive edition released via the [[Amazon Publishing]] imprint [[47North]], both in print and in [[Amazon Kindle|Kindle]] format. Fan-submitted Foreworld stories are published via Amazon's [[Kindle Worlds]] imprint.
==Collaborators and format== The serialized edition was intended to be distributed primarily as a series of applications ("apps") for [[smartphones]], which the Subutai Corporation viewed as a new model for publishing storytelling.<ref name=io9/> At the project's core is a narrative of adventure fiction following the exploits of a small group of fighters and mystics in medieval Europe around the time of the [[Mongol conquests]]. As well as speculative fiction authors [[Neal Stephenson]] (chairman of Subutai), [[Greg Bear]], [[Nicole Galland]], [[Mark Teppo]] and others, collaborators include filmmakers, computer programmers, graphic artists, martial artists and combat choreographers, video game designers, and a professional editor.<ref name=fast/> In a departure from conventional fiction, much of the content of ''The Mongoliad'' was in forms other than text, not bound to any single medium and not in the service of the central narrative. Once the project developed momentum, the Subutai Corporation envisioned fans of the work contributing, expanding and enriching the narrative, and the fictional universe in which it takes place.<ref name=io9/>
According to Jeremy Bornstein, president of the Subutai Corporation, the genesis of the project was in Stephenson's dissatisfaction with the authenticity of the early modern swordfighting scenes he had written into his series ''[[The Baroque Cycle]]''.<ref name=cnet/> Stephenson gathered a group of martial arts enthusiasts interested in studying historical European swordfighting, and this eventually resulted in some of the members of this group collaborating on a set of stories that would make use of accurate representations of these martial arts.<ref name=vimeo/><ref name=newitz/> The collaborators decided that the project need not limit itself to the traditional novel form and began developing ideas on how to produce it in different media while retaining the caliber that would be expected of a new work by authors such as Stephenson or Bear.<ref name=cnet/>
An "[[alpha version]]" was demonstrated at the periodic application showcase SF App Show in [[San Francisco, California]] on May 25, 2010.<ref name=cnet/><ref name=io9/>
The serialized project ran from September 1, 2010 until January 25, 2012. New chapters, as well as supplemental materials, were released on a semi-regular schedule. The iOS apps were available in the Apple App Store, and the Android app was available in the Android Store.<ref name=io9/> The print edition was published on April 24, 2012. The mongoliad.com website was subsequently closed.<ref name='closing'>{{cite web | url = http://foreworld.com/mongoliad/ | title = On the closing of mongoliad.com | accessdate = 2013-08-04}}</ref>
==Subject of the published ''Mongoliad'' books== The serial novels and their related, shorter "SideQuests" are set in the authors' "Foreworld" universe, which they describe as "almost like the world we live in," during the mid-thirteenth century [[Mongol invasion of Europe]], under leadership of [[Genghis Khan]] and his successor [[Ögedei Khan]]. The story includes descriptions of Ögedei Khan's court (notably, his rolling [[Orda (organization)#Etymology|"ordo" tent]]); the geography, flora and fauna of the great [[Eurasian Steppe]]; and especially [[Historical European martial arts#Early history .28before 1350.29|medieval European]] and Asian martial arts. A parallel plot line takes place in Rome, and includes highly detailed depictions of a [[Papal conclave#Conclaves|papal conclave]].
==Historical events and persons depicted in the ''Mongoliad'' series== The novels incorporate historical events in Poland, Rome, Russia and central Asia that ran concurrently with the last major events of the Mongol invasion. The authors construct a fictional narrative that connects all these events of the year 1241, describing some earlier historical events and adding other entirely fictional events and characters. Some medieval mythology is also included in the later books, especially the [[Holy Grail]] and elements of [[Norse mythology]].
Mongol events and persons described in the books include Ögedei's recollection of the 1201 battle of [[Khalakhaljid Sands]], which cemented Ghengis' leadership of the clans, and the 1229 death of his brother [[Tolui]], described in [[The Secret History of the Mongols]] as a heroic sacrifice to save Ögedei's life. Later, the 1241 death of Ögedei Khan (cause unknown) and the resulting recall of all the Khans to select a new "Khan of Khans" is woven into the fictional narrative.
The [[Siege of Kiev (1240)]] and other events in the [[Mongol invasion of Rus]] and Europe are described in 1241 by a survivor, as a group of the novel's fictional characters pass through the ruined city. The [[Battle of Mohi]] (Hungary) and the [[Battle of Legnica]] (Poland) are also described by fictional "survivors". Several religious orders of knights formed during the Crusades (and their leaders), including the [[Teutonic Order]], [[Knights Hospitaller]] and [[Livonian Brothers of the Sword]] are involved in the narrative.
Historical events and persons in 1241 Rome include the [[Papal election, 1241|papal conclave that selected Cardinal Castiglione]] to become [[Pope Celestine IV]]. Cardinal Fieschi (later [[Pope Innocent IV]]), and other future Popes are also members of the conclave. Senator [[Matteo Rosso Orsini]] and Holy Roman Emperor [[Frederick II, Holy Roman Emperor|Frederick II]] also appear as fictionalized characters.
[[Alexander Nevsky]]'s 1242 campaign against German and Estonian invaders is a major subject of Book 4, including the climactic [[Battle on the Ice]]. The mythical [[Baba Yaga]] helps the protagonists defend [[Kievan Rus']]. In Book 5, the action shifts to the [[Albigensian Crusade]] against [[Catharism]], and the 1244 siege of [[Château de Montségur]].
==Commercially published Foreworld Saga novels and short stories==
===''The Mongoliad Cycle''=== The series is identified interchangeably by the publisher as ''The Foreworld Saga'' and ''Mongoliad Cycle.'' * ''The Mongoliad, Book One,'' by Neal Stephenson, Erik Bear, Greg Bear, Joseph Brassey, Nicole Galland (aka E.D. deBirmingham<ref>{{cite web|last=Galland|first=Nicole|title=microblog post|url=https://www.facebook.com/nicolegalland/posts/10151193312052083|work=author's official profile|publisher=Facebook|accessdate=14 November 2013}}</ref>), Cooper Moo and Mark Teppo; April, 2012. * ''The Mongoliad, Book Two,'' by Neal Stephenson, Erik Bear, Greg Bear, Joseph Brassey, Nicole Galland (aka E.D. deBirmingham), Cooper Moo and Mark Teppo; September, 2012. * ''The Mongoliad, Book Three,'' by Neal Stephenson, Erik Bear, Greg Bear, Joseph Brassey, Nicole Galland (aka E.D. deBirmingham), Cooper Moo and Mark Teppo; February, 2013. * ''Katabasis, The Foreworld Saga, Book Four'', by Joseph Brassey, Cooper Moo, Mark Teppo and Angus Trim, October, 2013. (The first ''Foreworld'' novel not co-authored by Neal Stephenson.) * ''Siege Perilous, The Mongoliad Cycle, Book Five,'' by Nicole Galland (writing as E.D. deBirmingham); January, 2014
===Foreworld SideQuests=== The approximate page-count of each story places their literary format somewhere between a long [[short story]] and a short [[novella]], with the exception of the "Foreworld SideQuest Comics" which are in [[comics]] format. All were initially published in e-book and/or audio formats only. * ''Sinner'', by Mark Teppo; August, 2012. * ''Dreamer'', by Mark Teppo; September, 2012. * ''The [[Richard I of England|Lion]] in Chains'', by Mark Teppo; October, 2012. * ''The Shield Maiden'', by Michael Tinker Pearce and Linda Pearce; November, 2012. * ''The Beast of Calatrava'', by Mark Teppo; January, 2013. * ''Seer'', by Mark Teppo; February, 2013. * ''The Book of Seven Hands'', by Barth Anderson; March, 2013. * ''The Assassination of [[William the Silent|Orange]]'', by Joseph Brassey; April, 2013. * ''Hearts of Iron'', by Scott James Magner; May, 2013.<ref>https://www.amazon.com/dp/B00C1NYL1I/</ref> * ''Symposium #1'' (comic format), by [[Christian Cameron]] (author) and Dmitry Bondarenko (illustrator); July, 2013. * ''Tyr's Hammer'' by Michael Tinker Pearce and Linda Pearce; October, 2013. * ''Symposium #1'' (comic format), by Christian Cameron (author) and Dmitry Bondarenko (illustrator); October, 2013. * ''[[William Marshal, 1st Earl of Pembroke|Marshal]] versus the Assassins'', by M. Harold Page; November, 2013. * ''Blood and Ashes'', by Scott James Magner; February, 2014 <ref>https://www.amazon.com/dp/B00GM54GGG/</ref> * ''[[Suffrajitsu: Mrs. Pankhurst's Amazons]]'' (comic format), by Tony Wolf (author) and João Vieira (illustrator); January, 2015.
===Kindle World fan fiction stories=== In keeping with Subutai's original intent to augment the Foreworld Saga with fan or community content, [[fan fiction]] publisher [[Kindle Worlds]] published ten new stories "inspired by" the ''Foreworld Saga'' in June, 2013. ''Foreworld Saga'' co-author and [[showrunner]] Mark Teppo explains, "As you can see from the Kindle Worlds storefront, there is a distinction between Canon and Kindle Worlds material. We’d like to see some of the Kindle Worlds material elevate itself up to Canon by its quality."<ref>{{cite web|last=Teppo|first=Mark|title=Brave New Worlds (blog post)|url=http://foreworld.com/2013/06/27/brave-new-worlds/|work=Foreworld.com|publisher=Subutai Corp|accessdate=November 14, 2013}}</ref> * ''The Outcast'', by Robert Kroese; June, 2013. Taking place during the Viking invasions. * ''The Qian,'' by Aric Davis; June, 2013. Taking place during the Mongol war. * ''Kingdom of Glass,'' by Roberto Calas; June, 2013. Taking place toward the end of the [[Hundred Years War]]. * ''Sword of the Scholar'', by Mel Odom; June, 2013. Taking place during the [[Ming Dynasty]] China. * ''Bloodaxe,'' by Charles Sasser; June, 2013. Taking place during the Viking invasions. * ''The Brutus Coin'', by Leigh Knight; June, 2013. Taking place after the assassination of Julius Caesar. * ''Envoy,'' by Anselm Audley; June, 2013. Taking place during the wars of Attila the Hun. * ''Belly Full of Hell'', by Aric Davis; June, 2013. Pit fighting while taking place during the Mongol war. * ''The Mountain of Mist and Shadow,'' by S.M. Ruttan; June, 2013. Taking place during Julius Caesar's wars. * ''The Adventures of Dysingli Soon,'' by Joanna D. Jakubcin; June, 2013. Taking place in Medieval Rome. * ''Lanes of the Victorious,'' by Jon Mickus; January, 2014. Taking place during the [[First Mithridatic War]] of the Roman Republic. * ''Sword of Mongetai,'' by Richard Stiller; March, 2014. Taking place right after the Mongol invasions of [[Kievan Rus']]. * ''Out of the East,'' by Jerry Goodwyn; March, 2014. Taking place after the death of [[Pope Clement IV]]. * ''Infernal Castles,'' by Jon Mickus; July, 2014. The sequel to ''Lanes of the Victorious''. * ''Shield of Mongetai,'' by Richard Stiller; August, 2014. The sequel to ''Sword of Mongetai''. * ''The Veil of God,'' by R. Randolph Irwin; December, 2014.

revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{refimprove|date=May 2013}} {{No footnotes|date=January 2009}} }}
[[Image:Meller Allo.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Sketch of the decoration to the performance ''Hello, on the wave 477'' (1929)]] '''Vadym Meller''' or '''Vadim Meller''', ({{lang-ru|'''Вадим Георгиевич Меллер'''}};{{lang-uk|'''Вадим Георгійович Меллер'''}}, 1884–1962) was a [[Ukrainians|Ukrainian]]-[[Russians|Russian]] [[USSR|Soviet]] [[Painting|painter]], [[avant-garde]] [[Cubist]], [[Constructivism (art)|Constructivist]] and [[Expressionism (art)|Expressionist]] [[artist]], [[theater|theatrical]] [[designer]], [[book]] [[illustrator]], and [[architect]]. In 1925, he was the first artist to be awarded a gold medal in the ''[[Exposition Internationale des Arts Décoratifs et Industriels Modernes]]'' (''[[Art Deco]]'') in [[Paris]].
==Biography==
Vadim Meller was born in [[Saint-Petersburg]]. He was the second son of a top official in the [[Ministry of Justice]] in the [[Russian Empire]]. His father, George Meller, was a noble-born [[Swedish people|Swede]]; his mother, Helena Caruso, was half [[Italian people|Italian]] and half [[Greeks|Greek]], and also from a noble family. He married [[Nina Genke-Meller|Nina Genke]]. Vadim Meller died in Kiev.
==Education==
From 1903–1908, Meller studied at [[Kiev University]]. In 1905, he visited [[Geneva]], [[Switzerland]], where he took art lessons at the private school of [[Franz Roubaud]]. In 1908, with the recommendation of Roubaud, he continued his education at the private art school of drawing and painting of [[Heinrich Knirr]] in [[Munich]], [[Germany]]. There, Meller met fellow student, [[Paul Klee]], who introduced him to [[Der Blaue Reiter]] group.
After graduating from the [[Kiev University]] with a degree in law, he acquired an artistic education in the [[Munich]] [[Academy of Fine Arts, Munich|Academy of Fine Arts]] from 1908–1912. V. Meller stayed in close contact with [[Der Blaue Reiter]] group. During this time, he also met [[Wassily Kandinsky]], with whom he became friends.
==Work==
V.Meller started to exhibit his works after moving to [[Paris]], where he joined the [[Société des Artistes Indépendants]].At the same time Vadim Meller was a student of [[Antoine Bourdelle]]. In 1912–1914, together with [[Kazimir Malevich]], [[Sonia Delaunay]], [[Alexander Archipenko]], and [[Aleksandra Ekster]], he participated in a number of exhibitions ([[Salon des Indépendants]], Spring Salon, and Salon D' Automne) alongside [[Pablo Picasso]], [[Georges Braque]], and [[André Derain]].
After returning to [[Kiev]] in 1915, he worked at [[easel]] and [[monument]]al painting, [[graphic design]], and [[costume design]]. His transition to [[scenography]] as his main field of artistic activity took place in the post-[[Russian Revolution (1917)|revolutionary]] years. From 1918–1921, he worked with [[scenographer]] and dancer [[Bronislava Nijinska]] ([[Vaslav Nijinsky]]'s sister) in her [[ballet]] studio. In end of this period he became a professor in [[The National Academy of Fine Arts and Architecture]].
In 1922, [[Les Kurbas]] invited V. Meller to the recently founded Berezil' theater. <!--the apostrophe is part of the name-->
In 1925, V. Meller, together with Sonia Terk, Alexandra Exter, and [[Nathan Altman]], participated in ''[[Exposition Internationale des Arts Décoratifs et Industriels Modernes|Exposition Internationale des Modernes]]'' (''Art Deco'') in [[Paris]]. There, Meller was awarded a gold medal for his [[scenic design]] of the Berezil' theater. That same year, V.Meller participated in the ''International Theater Exposition'' in [[New York (state)|New York]].
V. Meller became the leader of the [[Constructivism (art)|Constructivism]] movement in Ukrainian [[theater]] [[design]]. He worked in the National theater as a chief artist until 1945. From 1925 onward, he also taught at the {{Interlanguage link multi|Kyiv Art Institute|WD=Q608690}} (KKHI) together with [[Vladimir Tatlin]] and [[Alexander Bogomazov]]. Also in 1925, V. Meller became a member of the artists union ''Association of the Revolutionary Masters of Ukraine'' together with [[David Burliuk]] (co-founder), [[Alexander Bogomazov]] (co-founder), [[Vasiliy Yermilov]], [[Victor Palmov]], and [[Khvostenko-Khvostov]].
In 1928 Vadim Meller participated in the International Press Exhibition ''Pressa'' [[Cologne]], together with [[El Lissitzky]], [[Aleksandr Tyshler]] and [[Vasyl Yermylov]].
V.Meller worked as an acting director of the Monumental Painting and Sculpture Institute of the Academy of Architecture of the [[Ukrainian SSR]] (1946–1948), a chief artist of the Kiev Music Comedy Theater (1948–1953), and a chief artist of the Iv. Franko Kiev Academic Theater (1953–1959).
== References == * ''Vadym Meller's Expressive Constructivism'', Olga Petrova, pp. 5–32, Catalog, an Exhibition ''Avant-Garde Adventures'', [[National Art Museum of Ukraine]] (NAMU), Kiev, Ukraine,2004. * ''Vadym Meller:Missionary of Avant-Garde Scenic Design'', Tetiana Rudenko, pp 46–68, book "Staging the Ukrainian Avant-Garde of the 1910s and 1920s", Ukrainian Museum, New York, US, 2015. * ''Vadim Meller'', Zoya Kucherenko, Mistetstvo, Kiev, 1975. *''Kyiv to Paris: Ukrainian Art in the European Avant-Garde'', 1905-1930, publication By Prof. Myroslav Shkandrij, Department of German and Slavic Studies University of Manitoba, Winnipeg, Canada, Zorya Fine Art, 2003. * ''Modernism in Kyiv: Jubilant Experimentation'', pp 3,5,11,219,229,257,264,299,415,426,430,492,497,501, etc. edited by Irena R. Makaryk., Virlana Tkacz., University of Toronto Press, 2010. * ''The World Encyclopedia of Contemporary Theatre. Europe'', pp. 872–4,883,885, volume 1, Editor Don Rubin, Routledge, Inc., New York, US, 1994.
== External links == * [http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/pages/M/E/MellerVadym.htm Encyclopedia of Ukraine on Vadym Meller] * [http://artinvestment.ru/en/auctions/4405/biography.html Biography on artinvestment.ru] * [http://uartlib.org/allbooks/z-v-kucherenko-vadim-meller/ Z.Kucherenko. Vadym Meller. Kyiv,1975] * [http://uartlib.org/allbooks/avantgarde_adventures/ Avant-garde Adventures. Vadym Meller, Nina Genke-Meller, Nina Vetrova-Robinson. Kyiv, 2004]

The '''Vettweiss-Froitzheim Dice Tower''' is a [[Roman Empire|Roman]] artifact, a [[dice tower]] formerly used in the playing of [[dice]] games.<ref name="RLB">{{cite web|url=http://www.rlmb.lvr.de/museum/meisterwerke/e0edb7e6-0f82-441f-bef0-80a4a4a32bdb.htm|title=A description of the tower at the Rheinisches Landesmuseum of Bonn|publisher=}}</ref> It was intended to produce a trustworthy throw of one or more dice. It was discovered in 1985 in Germany. It is preserved in the [[Rheinisches Landesmuseum Bonn|Rheinisches Landesmuseum]] of [[Bonn]].<ref name="RLB"/>
The tower dates to the fourth century AD and was apparently presented as a gift. It bears two [[Latin]] texts. The longer text commemorates a military defeat of the [[Picts]]. The shorter text wishes good luck to the unnamed recipients of the item.<ref name="RLB"/>
==Discovery==
The [[dice tower]] was discovered in 1985 near the modern villages of [[Vettweiß|Vettweiss and Froitzheim]]. During the Roman era this location was in the province of [[Germania Inferior]] on the [[Rhine|Imperial frontier]] with [[Germanic peoples|Germania]]. This was the site of a [[Roman villa|villa]] in the German state of [[North Rhine-Westphalia]]. The major military centre of [[Colonia Claudia Ara Agrippinensium|Cologne]] was located nearby.
==Description== It is an upright, hollow cuboid of copper-alloy plate designed to sit level on a flat surface. The top of the dice tower is open, allowing for the introduction of dice, and it contains three levels of projecting baffles which would produce random motion in the dice as they fell through the tower.<ref name="RLB"/> The dice would then emerge at the base of the tower via a miniature flight of steps. The dice, while emerging, would ring three bells which formerly hung above the exit. One of these bells survives intact.<ref name="RLB"/>
The tower is decorated on all faces with pierced patterns and two short Latin texts are displayed prominently.<ref name="RLB"/>
The front face of the tower bears the words,
:PICTOS VICTOS :HOSTIS DELETA :LVDITE SECVRI
Which may be translated as,
:The Picts are defeated. :The enemy is destroyed. :Play in safety!
Around the top of the three remaining faces is the phrase,
:UTERE FELIX VIVAS
Which may be translated as,
:Use it and live luckily/happily.<ref name="RLB"/>
